items.title: Streaming service Plex gets more social with public profiles and reviews
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Plex expands its social networking features to allow users to create public profiles and share their TV/movie reviews.
- Users can now share a public URL to their profiles and control the visibility of their ratings and reviews.
- Changes aim to help Plex compete with other free streaming services and dedicated social networks for reviews.
- Plex Pass subscribers get access to HEVC hardware encoding for improved video quality and lower bandwidth use.

items.title: Zombie nuclear reactors could be revived thanks to AI data center demand
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Santee Cooper aims to restart construction on the Virgil C. Summer Nuclear Power Station, halted in 2017 due to budget overruns.
- The original project cost escalated from $9.8 billion to $25 billion, contributing to Westinghouse's bankruptcy.
- Interest in nuclear power is rising due to demand from AI data centers, with potential partnerships being sought by Santee Cooper.
- Microsoft and Meta are involved in related nuclear power initiatives to secure energy for their operations.
- There are political challenges related to the financing of the project that could impact ratepayers.
keywords: Virgil C. Summer Nuclear Power Station

items.title: Samsung Unpacked: The Samsung Galaxy S25’s side button fires up Google Gemini
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung announced new features for the Galaxy S25, including easier access to Google Gemini via the side button.
- The update follows the struggle with Samsung's Bixby and the replacement of Google Home by Gemini on Android.
- The Galaxy S25 features improved AI capabilities powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite chip and offers cross-app functionality with Google apps.
- Preorders for the Galaxy S25 line start now, with shipping set for February 7, 2025.

items.title: Samsung Unpacked: Google makes Circle to Search more helpful
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announced updates to Circle to Search at [Samsung Unpacked 2025](https://techcrunch.com/storyline/samsung-unpacked-2025-live-updates-galaxy-s25-new-ai-features-and-more/).
- Circle to Search allows users to search information using gestures like circling and highlighting.
- New AI Overviews expand to visual results without needing additional text.
- Users can circle items, such as artwork, for AI-generated information and links.
- Functionality is rolling out on all Android devices.

items.title: Samsung Unpacked 2025: Samsung Galaxy S25 line compared
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung announced the Galaxy S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra during Samsung Unpacked 2025 on January 22, 2025.
- The devices focus on AI enhancements, utilizing Google's Gemini platform.
- Preorders for all models began immediately, with shipping set for February 7, 2025.
- Galaxy S25 features: 6.2-inch FHD+, Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite, 4,000 mAh battery, starting at $800.
- Galaxy S25+ features: 6.7-inch QHD+, Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite, 4,900 mAh battery, starting at $1,000.
- Galaxy S25 Ultra features: 6.9-inch QHD+, 200MP rear camera, 5,000 mAh battery, starting at $1,300.

items.title: Samsung’s SmartThings to introduce AI features that simplify your daily routines
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Samsung introduced AI features for SmartThings at Samsung Unpacked 2025.
- New ‘Home AI’ features will use ambient sensing technology and generative AI for personalized experiences.
- Advanced sensor technology like mmWave and sound sensors will detect user activities (e.g., cooking, exercising) to optimize home settings.
- Users can take pictures of objects for SmartThings' Map View technology to enhance device interaction.
- All data will be stored locally, ensuring privacy and consent for data use.
- Rollout of updates planned for 2025 and 2026.

items.title: Samsung’s AI-focused Galaxy S25 Ultra ships February 7 for $1,300
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung unveiled the Galaxy S25 series, focusing on mobile AI at the annual Samsung Unpacked 2025.
- The Galaxy S25 Ultra, priced at $1,300, features a 6.9-inch display and a quad-camera setup with a 50MP ultra-wide and 200MP wide cameras.
- It is powered by the Snapdragon 8 Elite chip, promising significant performance boosts across CPU, GPU, and NPU.
- The device supports AI image sharpening and enhanced gaming graphics with the Snapdragon's advanced features.
- Google’s AI tools are integrated, including long-press access to Gemini and new AI writing features.
- The Ultra has a 5,000mAh battery, 12GB of RAM, and up to 1TB storage, with preorder starting Wednesday and shipping on February 7.

items.title: The Samsung Galaxy S25’s side button fires up Google Gemini
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung Galaxy S25 line announced with new features for easier access to Google Gemini via the side button.
- This announcement follows Samsung's struggle to promote its Bixby assistant and comes as Gemini replaces Google Home on Android devices.
- Galaxy S25 to ship on February 7, with preorders currently available.

items.title: Samsung Unpacked 2025: Google is bringing improved hearing aid features
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Google announced accessibility improvements for Android during Samsung Unpacked 2025, enhancing hearing aid functionality and screen reader features.
- Updates include LE Bluetooth compatibility for hands-free calling and lower latency, rolling out with Android 16 beta updates on Galaxy S25, S24, and Pixel 9.
- The improved TalkBack screen reader will also support braille users with new HID functionality and better image descriptions from Google Gemini.

items.title: Google makes Circle to Search more helpful
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google announced updates to Circle to Search at [Samsung Unpacked 2025](https://techcrunch.com/storyline/samsung-unpacked-2025-live-updates-galaxy-s25-new-ai-features-and-more/) to enhance user information retrieval on Android devices.
- The update expands AI Overviews for various visual results without needing to add extra text to searches.
- Users can now get quick AI snapshots of information by circling items like artwork in museums, as well as action chips for recognized numbers, email addresses, and URLs on their screens.

items.title: Samsung’s Galaxy S25 arrives with a better Google Gemini
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Samsung unveiled the Galaxy S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra at Unpacked 2025.
- An improved Google AI assistant, Gemini, was launched, allowing multi-app actions in one prompt.
- New Gemini Extensions were introduced for Samsung Calendar, Clock, Notes, and Reminder.
- Gemini Live, a voice-based feature, offers a multimodal conversational experience, including uploads of images and videos.
- Future enhancements involve Project Astra capabilities, including screen sharing and live streaming.
- The Galaxy S25 series has a new side button for quick access to Gemini tasks.
- Preorders for the Galaxy S25 series started, with shipping set for February 7.

items.title: Samsung Galaxy S25 line compared
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung unveiled three new Galaxy models: S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra at [Samsung Unpacked 2025](https://techcrunch.com/storyline/samsung-unpacked-2025-live-updates-galaxy-s25-new-ai-features-and-more/).
- Preorders are available now; shipping starts on February 7.
- Key specifications:
  - Display: S25 (6.2-inch FHD+), S25+ (6.7-inch QHD+), S25 Ultra (6.9-inch QHD+)
  - Front Camera: All models feature a 12-megapixel front camera.
  - Rear Camera: S25 and S25+ have a three-camera setup; S25 Ultra has a four-camera setup with a 200-megapixel main sensor.
  - Processor: All models utilize the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite Mobile Platform.
  - Battery: S25 (4,000 mAh), S25+ (4,900 mAh), S25 Ultra (5,000 mAh).
  - Storage: S25 (128GB/256GB), S25+ (256GB/512GB), S25 Ultra (256GB/512GB/1TB).
  - Starting Prices: S25 ($800), S25+ ($1,000), S25 Ultra ($1,300).

items.title: Elon Musk and Sam Altman take to social media to fight over Stargate
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk and Sam Altman are publicly arguing on social media about the Stargate project for OpenAI’s data centers.
- Stargate aims to attract $500 billion for developing data centers across the U.S., with initial commitments of $100 billion.
- Musk disputes the project's financial backing, claiming SoftBank has less than $10 billion secured.
- Altman counters Musk’s claims, promoting Stargate as beneficial for the country and emphasizes his respect for Musk.
- Musk leads the DOGE commission, which aims to reduce federal spending, amidst its legal challenges.
- Industry responses include Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella affirming his company’s $80 billion commitment to AI data centers.

items.title: Samsung Unpacked 2025: Here’s how to watch and what we expect
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Samsung Unpacked event scheduled for January 22, 2025, at 10 a.m. PT, 1 p.m. ET.
- The event will be streamed on [Samsung’s site](https://www.samsung.com/us/smartphones/the-next-galaxy/reserve/) and [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HinL5jCy_oI&ab_channel=Samsung).
- Preorders are encouraged with a $50 Samsung store credit for reservations made before the event.
- Expected to reveal the Galaxy S25 series, including models S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra.
- Anticipated design changes include a slimmer profile and upgraded Snapdragon 8 Elite chip.
- Galaxy AI will be highlighted, aiming to differentiate from Google’s offerings.
- Potential additional reveals include a Galaxy Ring wearable and Project Moohan extended reality headset.

items.title: Livestream app Favorited, a new TikTok alternative, gets backing from a16z
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Favorited, a new livestream app, recently announced $1.3 million in pre-seed funding.
- The app features gifting, interactive games, and a 70/30 revenue split for creators.
- Founded by David Tesler and Zach Ferraro, it aims to gamify livestreams and promote real-time interaction.
- Over 750,000 users have joined, with notable earnings reported by some creators.
- The app is available on both the App Store and Google Play Store, boasting 1.3 million installs.

items.title: Trump administration fires members of cybersecurity review board in “horribly shortsighted” decision
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- The Department of Homeland Security fired members of various advisory committees on January 21, 2025, including the Cyber Security Review Board (CSRB).
- Critics describe the decision as short-sighted, particularly given ongoing cyber threats from China.
- The CSRB was instrumental in understanding cybersecurity threats to the U.S., including recent breaches linked to Chinese hackers.
- The rationale cited for the firings was ‘misuse of resources,’ despite advisory board members receiving no salary.
- There are concerns about filling advisory positions with qualified individuals regardless of political affiliation.

items.title: Dewey launches a solution to save your TikTok favorites … just in case
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- TikTok has launched a backup service called [Dewey](https://getdewey.co/) to save favorite videos in case the app goes offline again.
- The service allows users to access saved TikTok favorites and collections permanently.
- Dewey was originally created for Twitter and has expanded to support multiple social media platforms.
- Users can now conveniently pull TikTok Favorites into their Dewey feed, with dedicated folders for easy access.
- Dewey offers a free service for one account; paid plans start at $7.50 per month for unlimited backups and additional features.
- The team began working on this TikTok solution due to its uncertain future following management decisions regarding U.S. operations.

items.title: YouTube launches speed controls and high-quality audio tests for Premium users
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- YouTube introduces new experimental features for Premium users, including high-quality audio at up to 256kbps.
- Mobile users can now play videos at a speed of up to 4x and utilize picture-in-picture mode for Shorts.
- Smart downloads for Shorts are being added to iOS, automatically downloading videos based on a good connection.
- The 'Jump Ahead' feature is now available on the web, allowing users to skip to engaging parts of videos based on AI analysis.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 tickets now on sale: Lowest rates ever
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 tickets are on sale with the lowest rates of the year available until January 31.
- The event will take place from October 27–29 at Moscone West in San Francisco, featuring over 250 sessions and 200 discussions.
- Attendees can register for 2-for-1 passes and super early bird rates, saving up to $1,100 before February 28.

items.title: Anthropic reportedly secures an additional $1B from Google
items.summary:
- Anthropic raised approximately $1 billion from Google, increasing Google's total investment to roughly $3 billion.
- Google had previously invested $2 billion in Anthropic in late 2024.
- Anthropic plans to launch new AI models and features, including two-way voice chat and web access for its chatbot Claude, in 2025.
- The company's ambitious plans include introducing a new AI system called the “Virtual Collaborator.”
- Anthropic has raised a total of $14.7 billion to date.

items.title: Conduent confirms outage was due to a cybersecurity incident
items.author: Sean Collins
items.summary:
- U.S. government contractor Conduent confirmed outage caused by a cybersecurity incident.
- Outage affected access to support payments for some U.S. residents.
- Conduent spokesperson stated incident was contained and services restored; details on data exfiltration were not disclosed.

items.title: AI apps saw over $1 billion in consumer spending in 2024
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Consumer spending on apps reached $150 billion globally in 2024, a 13% increase from the previous year.
- AI apps experienced a 200% year-over-year increase in consumer spending, totaling nearly $1.1 billion.
- ChatGPT achieved 50 million monthly active users quickly, highlighting growing interest in AI apps.
- The report from Sensor Tower provides insight into trends across various app categories, including e-commerce and finance.

items.title: Trump open to Elon Musk or Larry Ellison buying TikTok
items.summary:
- President Donald Trump is open to Tesla CEO Elon Musk or Oracle chairman Larry Ellison buying TikTok in a venture with the U.S. government.
- Trump confirmed his openness to the idea during a press conference, encouraging the potential purchase by both Musk and Ellison.
- An executive order signed by Trump delayed the TikTok ban deadline by 75 days and halted the enforcement of penalties while the app remains offline in app stores.
- Trump is considering a deal where the U.S. government would allow TikTok to operate if half of the company is given to the U.S.

items.title: Databricks closes $15.3B financing at $62B valuation, Meta joins as ‘strategic investor’
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Databricks has completed a $15.3 billion financing round at a $62 billion valuation, including $10 billion in Series J equity and $5.25 billion in debt financing.
- The debt financing involved major banks such as JPMorgan Chase, Barclays, and Goldman Sachs.
- Databricks plans to invest the new funding into AI products and global operations and hinted at potential IPO plans for 2025.

items.title: What PowerSchool isn’t saying about its ‘massive’ student data breach
items.summary:
- PowerSchool confirmed a major data breach affecting its K-12 software used by over 18,000 schools and about 60 million students in the U.S.
- The breach occurred through compromised credentials on the PowerSource portal, lacking multi-factor authentication (MFA).
- The incident was reported on December 28, 2024, and details indicate potential access to sensitive information, including Social Security numbers and medical data.
- The scale of the breach is unknown; however, some affected schools have reported extensive historical data theft.
- PowerSchool has not disclosed how much it paid hackers, nor the identities of the threat actors involved in the breach.
- The company stated it took steps to prevent the stolen data from being published but has not confirmed the evidence of data deletion.

items.title: Ramp Encroaches into Digital Bank Territory with New Treasury Product
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- Ramp introduces a new product called Ramp Treasury, expanding into digital banking territory.
- The product allows businesses to earn 2.5% on stored cash or potentially higher yields through money market funds.
- Ramp partners with First Internet Bank of Indiana and Apex for this treasury offering; it aims to complement, not replace, existing bank accounts.
- The company currently has over 30,000 customers and powered over $50 billion in transactions.
- Ramp has not had layoffs and raised $150 million at a post-money valuation of $7.65 billion in April 2024.

items.title: Postman launches an AI agent builder on top of its API platform
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- Postman announces an AI agent builder that integrates large language models with its API platform.
- The platform includes a visual editor targeted at non-developers for building and testing AI agents.
- Postman aims to enhance API interaction for various user types, as API connections are crucial for AI functionality.
- The new service allows users to create AI agents that interact with APIs from an extensive API hub contributed by over 18,000 companies.
- Features will include tools for testing and evaluation of AI prompts across supported models like OpenAI and Google's Gemini.
- The focus is currently on back-end operations, with future plans to evolve interaction modalities.

items.title: Sales knowledge automation platform 1up gets a third of its customer leads from memes
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- 1up is an AI-powered knowledge automation platform for sales teams, launched in 2022 by George Avetisov after his time at HYPR.
- The platform assists sales professionals in finding answers to product questions and filling out technical questionnaires using internal data sources.
- 1up has gained nearly 100 customers, attributing a third of its leads to meme-based marketing on platforms like LinkedIn.
- Recently announced a $5 million funding round led by Upfront Ventures, with participation from others including RRE Ventures.
- The company aims to enhance sales team tools and differentiate itself from AI sales lead generators already in the market.

items.title: Doti gives enterprises a flexible AI-powered search experience to unlock their data silos
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- Doti AI, a startup based in Tel Aviv, has raised $7 million in seed funding to enhance enterprise search using AI.
- The platform integrates data from various services like Confluence, Jira, and Slack, enabling a chat-based search experience.
- Co-founders Matan Cohen and Opher Hofshi emphasize flexibility, allowing businesses to integrate their own large language models and security policies.

items.title: Lindus Health raises $55M to ‘fix the broken clinical trial industry’
items.summary:
- Lindus Health, a London startup, raised $55 million in a Series B funding round.
- The company aims to streamline the clinical trial process using AI and automation, calling itself the “anti-CRO.”
- Founded in 2021, Lindus has conducted trials for various conditions, enrolling over 35,000 patients and focusing on neglected health issues.
- The CRO market is projected to grow from $82 billion to $130 billion by 2030, highlighting the industry's significance.
- Lindus plans to use the new funding for expansion, including moving its headquarters to the U.S. and enhancing its product offerings.

items.title: Google hit with $12.6M fine in Indonesia for monopolistic practices in payment system
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- Indonesia’s antitrust agency KPPU fined Google 202.5 billion Rupiahs ($12.6 million) for antitrust violation regarding its payment system in the Google Play Store.
- The KPPU mandated Google to cease mandatory use of Google Play Billing and allowed developers to participate in the [User Choice Billing program](https://techcrunch.com/2022/11/10/google-play-to-pilot-third-party-billing-in-new-markets-including-u-s-bumble-joins-spotify-as-early-tester/).
- The agency's investigation revealed Google required Indonesian developers to use Google Play Billing, which charged fees up to 30%, leading to reduced app usage and revenue.
- Google holds a 50% market share of the Google Play Store and a 95.16% share in the Indonesian search engine market as of January 2024, according to [Statista](https://www.statista.com/statistics/954420/indonesia-market-share-of-search-engines/).
- Google plans to appeal the KPPU's decision, defending its practices as fostering a competitive app ecosystem.

items.title: Hindustan Unilever acquires Peak XV-backed Minimalist for over $340M
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Hindustan Unilever will acquire beauty startup Minimalist for approximately $342 million.
- Initial acquisition will involve a 90.5% stake, with the remaining 9.5% to be purchased in two years.
- This acquisition strengthens Unilever's presence in India's premium skincare market, complementing its existing portfolio of brands.
- Minimalist has reported an annual revenue run rate of over 5 billion rupees and has been profitable since its inception.
- The deal is expected to close in the June quarter, pending regulatory approvals.

items.title: UK appoints ex-Amazon executive Doug Gurr as interim chair of antitrust body
items.summary:
- Doug Gurr, former Amazon executive, appointed as interim chairman of the U.K.’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA).
- The appointment aligns with the U.K.'s goal to enhance pro-tech and pro-business initiatives.
- Gurr has a rich background at Amazon, transitioning from roles in hardlines and country management to leading U.K. operations.
- CMA’s focus includes a significant ongoing investigation into the domestic cloud services market where Amazon is heavily involved.
- Outgoing chair Marcus Bokkerink's short tenure prompted this leadership change as U.K. regulators seek a more commercial approach toward antitrust enforcement.
- Gurr's appointment may influence CMA's strategies toward big tech companies amid evolving regulatory powers under the Digital Markets Competition and Consumer Act.

items.title: Indian fintech Jar turns cash flow positive
items.summary:
- Indian fintech startup Jar confirmed it has turned cash flow positive as of January 22, 2025.
- The three-year-old company showed over 10 times growth last year.
- Jar is focusing on profitability as many Indian startups prepare for IPOs.
- The startup expanded its offerings to include lending and online jewelry sales, generating approximately $13 million in annual sales from its jewelry segment, Nek.
- Jar is currently in talks to raise up to $50 million in a new funding round, though they declined to comment on these discussions.

items.title: Vertice raises $50M for its AI-powered SaaS spend platform
items.summary:
- Vertice raised $50 million in Series C funding to expand its AI-driven expenditure management platform.
- The company has grown 13x since its inception, capitalizing on the increasing software and cloud spend.
- CEO Roy Tuvey emphasized the platform aims to standardize purchasing processes across various categories, not limited to software.
- Investors include Lakestar, CF Private Equity, Perpetual Growth, and previous backers like Bessemer Venture Partners.
- Vertice has raised around $100 million to date, and the latest funding values the company higher than its previous multi-hundred million valuation.
- Their clientele includes significant companies across Europe, the U.S., and Asia Pacific, such as ASML and Santander.
- Vertice utilizes AI to ingest contract data and streamline procurement, potentially cutting purchase cycles in half and achieving savings of 20-30%.

items.title: Truecaller brings real-time caller ID to iPhone users
items.author: Jagmeet Singh, Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Truecaller now offers real-time caller ID for iPhone users, a feature previously available to Android users.
- The update is made possible through Apple’s Live Caller ID Lookup introduced in iOS 18, allowing secure lookups of caller information.
- Truecaller has over 2.6 million paying subscribers, with 750,000 on iOS, contributing to 40% of its revenue, highlighting the importance of iPhone users in the company’s revenue model.
- The app had previously updated its iOS version in 2023, but this recent update marks the first major change post-co-founders' departure in November 2024.
- Truecaller’s premium tier for iOS starts at $9.99/month, with family plans also available, and the company is developing support for images in caller ID.

items.title: Trump pardons Silk Road creator Ross Ulbricht
items.summary:
- President Trump pardoned Ross Ulbricht, creator of Silk Road, on January 21, 2025.
- The pardon was announced via a [Truth Social post](https://truthsocial.com/@realDonaldTrump/113869112741612092) and was in honor of Ulbricht’s mother and the Libertarian movement.
- Ulbricht was sentenced to life in prison in 2015 for operating Silk Road as “Dread Pirate Roberts” but Trump had promised to commute his sentence during the 2024 campaign.

items.title: Mr Beast is reportedly now among those trying to buy TikTok
items.summary:
- Mr Beast is part of a group submitting an all-cash bid to acquire TikTok.
- The bid is led by Jessie Tinsley, CEO of Employer.com, aiming to save the app.
- The amount of the bid has not been disclosed, and legal counsel includes Brad Bondi.
- TikTok recently faced a brief service outage amid potential regulatory actions.
- Other potential buyers include Elon Musk, Amazon, Oracle, and Frank McCourt.

items.title: Meta COO Sheryl Sandberg sanctioned by judge for allegedly deleting emails
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- A judge in Delaware sanctioned Sheryl Sandberg, Meta's former COO, for deleting emails related to the [Cambridge Analytica privacy scandal](https://techcrunch.com/tag/cambridge-analytica/).
- Plaintiffs accused Sandberg and former board member Jeff Zients of using personal emails to discuss a 2018 shareholder lawsuit concerning user privacy.
- The judge raised the standard for Sandberg's defense to "clear and convincing" evidence and awarded plaintiffs certain expenses.
- The case relates to allegations that Meta violated a 2012 FTC order by improperly handling users' data, which led to a $5 billion settlement with the FTC in 2019.

items.title: Microsoft is no longer OpenAI’s exclusive cloud provider
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft was the exclusive provider of data center infrastructure for OpenAI but is no longer the sole provider.
- OpenAI has signed a new agreement with Microsoft, granting Microsoft the "right of first refusal" on new cloud computing capacity, allowing OpenAI to seek other providers if needed.
- Microsoft made a significant Azure commitment to support OpenAI products, and key partnership elements will remain in place through 2030, including revenue sharing and access to OpenAI's intellectual property.
- If OpenAI achieves artificial general intelligence under their agreed-upon definition, Microsoft could lose access to OpenAI’s technology if OpenAI generates $100 billion in profits.
- OpenAI is reportedly considering nullifying the agreement with Microsoft to secure more funding.

items.title: OpenAI teams up with SoftBank and Oracle on $500B data center project
items.summary:
- OpenAI, SoftBank, and Oracle will create The Stargate Project for building AI data centers in the U.S.
- Initial investment of $100 billion, with potential growth to $500 billion over four years.
- The project aims to create hundreds of thousands of jobs and enhance national security.
- First data center to be located in Texas, with plans for expansion across the country.
- SoftBank and OpenAI are lead partners, with SoftBank holding financial, and OpenAI operational responsibilities.
- Microsoft, Arm, Nvidia, and MGX are also involved in the project.
- Concerns raised about environmental impacts and labor job creation from data centers.
- Trump announced the project at a White House press conference, emphasizing infrastructure investment.

items.title: Scale AI’s Alexandr Wang has published an open letter lobbying Trump to invest in AI
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Alexandr Wang, CEO of Scale AI, published a full-page ad in The Washington Post urging the Trump administration to invest in AI.
- The ad, dated January 21, 2025, emphasizes the need for the U.S. to "win the AI War" against China.
- Wang outlines five recommendations for the administration, including increasing AI spending, making federal agencies AI-ready by 2027, and improving regulations for AI-related jobs.
- Concerns have been raised about framing U.S.-China AI competition as a "war."
- Wang argues that the competition is intensifying as China accelerates its AI investments and capabilities.

items.title: Amperesand targets data centers as the next big customer for its solid-state transformers
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Data centers are projected to consume up to 12% of U.S. electricity by 2028, increasing from 90 gigawatts globally in 2023 to over 185 gigawatts.
- Amperesand develops solid-state transformers using silicon carbide, which are more efficient at voltage regulation and can integrate multiple power sources.
- The company is raising a Series A round after a $12.5 million seed round and plans to open an office in the U.S. to tap local talent.

items.title: Startup founders flooded inauguration parties hopeful for dealmaking
items.author: Margaux Maccoll
items.summary:
- Tech founders attended various inauguration parties in Washington, D.C., seeking connections with the new administration.
- Isaiah Taylor, founder of Valar Atomics, networked by sending proposals to DC insiders, expressing a desire for nuclear regulation changes.
- Founders enjoyed celebrity appearances and events, such as Snoop Dogg at a crypto party and others hosted by conservative groups.
- Tyler Sweatt of Second Front Systems noted frustrations with government bureaucracy but felt optimistic about alignment between startups and the new administration.
- Many founders expressed hopes that the Trump administration could enhance government efficiency and technology integration.
- James Layfield of Samplify.ai aims to offer government services for free to improve efficiency under the new government guidelines.
- Rabi Alam of Counter Health is exploring opportunities with DOGE to enhance healthcare operations amid the political atmosphere.

items.title: Meta is building Oakley smart glasses for athletes: report
items.summary:
- Meta's Reality Labs is developing AI smart glasses branded by Oakley, aimed at athletes.
- The glasses will use a design based on Oakley's Sphaera model and feature a camera positioned at the center of the frame.
- Meta aims to leverage Oakley's popularity among athletes like cyclists, runners, and rowers to boost the appeal of smart glasses.
- In addition to these glasses, Meta is working on camera-equipped earbuds, a smartwatch, and a $1,000 pair of smart glasses with a projected AR display.

items.title: Perplexity launches Sonar, an API for AI search
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Perplexity launched an API service called Sonar, enabling integration of generative AI search tools into applications.
- Sonar features real-time internet connections for more factual and authoritative answers, with two tiers: base Sonar and Sonar Pro.
- Sonar is the cheapest AI search API available, with pricing options for developers based on searches and token usage.
- Zoom is already implementing Sonar for real-time AI assistance in video calls, enhancing user experience without interruption.
- Sonar Pro claims to outperform major competitors like Google and OpenAI on factual correctness benchmarks.
- Perplexity recently raised $73.6 million, highlighting a growth strategy amid increasing competition in the AI space.

items.title: Trump targets EV charging funding programs Tesla benefits from
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- President Trump aims to halt funding from two programs benefiting Tesla, impacting EV charging infrastructure financing.
- His executive order directs agencies to pause disbursement from the Inflation Reduction Act and Bipartisan Infrastructure Law.
- The order affects EV charging funds, specifically the NEVI Formula Program and the CFI grant program.
- Tesla previously received significant funding to enhance its charging network, including a recent $100 million award for electric truck charging.
- Trump’s move may legally challenge existing contracts but hints at potential delays in funding, creating barriers for EV infrastructure growth.

items.title: Govtech giant Conduent won’t rule out cyberattack as outage drags on
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Conduent is experiencing a prolonged service interruption affecting multiple U.S. states, disrupting access to benefits and payments.
- Sources indicate a potential cyberattack as the cause; Conduent has not provided further details.
- Affected states include Wisconsin, with issues related to child support payments, restored by January 19.
- Oklahoma Human Services reported disruptions but claimed no security outages at Conduent.
- Conduent previously faced a ransomware attack in June 2020, attributed to the Maze gang.

items.title: Spotify’s educational audio courses could be coming to US
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Spotify is expanding its service to include educational courses in addition to music, podcasts, and audiobooks.
- The feature is currently being piloted in the U.K. with indications it may arrive in the U.S. soon.
- Early adopter Chris Messina discovered the courses can be accessed in the U.S., although the category pages were empty, indicating ongoing development.
- Courses cover topics like AI, web3, and more, appealing to a technical audience.
- Spotify aims to diversify its revenue by monetizing educational content, similar to its efforts with podcasts and audiobooks.

items.title: Spotify introduces educational audio courses, starting in the UK
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
• Spotify has launched educational audio courses alongside its music and podcast offerings, starting in the U.K.
• The new feature aims to cover topics in business, tech, lifestyle, and music.
• Spotify plans to diversify its revenue stream through ads and potential paid courses.
• Initial recommended courses include topics like self-care, vegetarian cooking, and communication fundamentals.
• Courses may soon allow filtering only “Podcasts & Courses” in users' libraries.
• While U.S. availability is uncertain, some users have accessed courses, indicating ongoing development.
